message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modeling Public Mood and Emotion: Twitter Sentiment and Socio-Economic Phenomena
Paper Abstract: We perform a sentiment analysis of all tweets published on the microblogging platform Twitter in the second half of 2008. We use a psychometric instrument to extract six mood states (tension, depression, anger, vigor, fatigue, confusion) from the aggregated Twitter content and compute a six-dimensional mood vector for each day in the timeline. We compare our results to a record of popular events gathered from media and sources. We find that events in the social, political, cultural and economic sphere do have a significant, immediate and highly specific effect on the various dimensions of public mood. We speculate that large scale analyses of mood can provide a solid platform to model collective emotive trends in terms of their predictive value with regards to existing social as well as economic indicators.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Overview

Twitter is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.(no content)Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts (commonly and unofficially known as "tweets") and like other users' content.

## History and Growth

Twitter was created by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in March 2006 and was launched that July.(no content)On April 25, 2022, Twitter agreed to a $44 billion buyout by Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla.(no content)Twitter, Inc. was merged with X Corp. in April 2023.

## User Base

By the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users. More recently, as of December 2025, Elon Musk, businessman and owner of the website, has the most-followed account with over 229 million followers.

## Features

Twitter Spaces is a social audio feature that enables users to host or participate in a live-audio virtual environment called space for conversation. A maximum of 13 people are allowed onstage. The feature was initially limited to users with at least 600 followers, but since October 2021, any Twitter user can create a Space.

Twitter is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.(no content)Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts (commonly and unofficially known as "tweets") and like other users' content.

## History and Growth

Twitter was created by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in March 2006 and was launched that July.(no content)On April 25, 2022, Twitter agreed to a $44 billion buyout by Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla.(no content)Twitter, Inc. was merged with X Corp. in April 2023.

## User Base

By the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users. More recently, as of December 2025, Elon Musk, businessman and owner of the website, has the most-followed account with over 229 million followers.

## Features

Twitter Spaces is a social audio feature that enables users to host or participate in a live-audio virtual environment called space for conversation. A maximum of 13 people are allowed onstage. The feature was initially limited to users with at least 600 followers, but since October 2021, any Twitter user can create a Space.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Economic indicators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Economic_indicators"},{"title":"Economic indicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_indicator"},{"title":"Category:Lists by economic indicators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Lists_by_economic_indicators"},{"title":"Blue Chip Economic Indicators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Chip_Economic_Indicators"},{"title":"Category:Global economic indicators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Global_economic_indicators"},{"title":"Category:Lists of countries by economic indicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Lists_of_countries_by_economic_indicator"},{"title":"OECD Main Economic Indicators - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OECD_Main_Economic_Indicators"},{"title":"Women in America: Indicators of Social and Economic Well-Being - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women_in_America:_Indicators_of_Social_and_Economic_Well-Being"},{"title":"Conference Board Leading Economic Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conference_Board_Leading_Economic_Index"},{"title":"List of economic reports by U.S. government agencies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_economic_reports_by_U.S._government_agencies"}]

Here are the results from the web search on economic indicators:

## Overview

An economic indicator is a statistic about an economic activity that allows analysis of economic performance and predictions of future performance.

## Types of Economic Indicators

Economic indicators include various indices, earnings reports, and economic summaries such as the unemployment rate, quits rate, housing starts, consumer price index, inverted yield curve, consumer leverage ratio, industrial production, bankruptcies, gross domestic product, broadband internet penetration, retail sales, price index, and changes in credit conditions.(no content)Leading indicators are indicators that usually change before the economy as a whole changes and are therefore useful as short-term predictors of the economy.(no content)Leading indicators include the index of consumer expectations, building permits, and credit conditions.(no content)Lagging indicators are indicators that usually change after the economy as a whole does, typically with a lag of a few quarters of a year.(no content)Coincident indicators change at approximately the same time as the whole economy and provide information about the current state of the economy, including measures such as Gross Domestic Product, industrial production, personal income and retail sales.

## Key Publications

The Conference Board publishes a composite Leading Economic Index consisting of ten indicators designed to predict activity in the U.S. economy six to nine months in future.(no content)OECD Main Economic Indicators is a monthly publication by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development of economic indicators worldwide with a focus on OECD countries.

Web search results for query: "Sentiment analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal sentiment analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_sentiment_analysis"},{"title":"Sentiment analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentiment_analysis"},{"title":"Market sentiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Market_sentiment"},{"title":"General Sentiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Sentiment"},{"title":"Lexalytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexalytics"},{"title":"MeaningCloud - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MeaningCloud"},{"title":"News analytics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_analytics"},{"title":"Text mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text_mining"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2013-04-29/Recent research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2013-04-29/Recent_research"},{"title":"Topsy Labs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topsy_(analytics)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of sentiment analysis:

## Definition

Sentiment analysis (also known as opinion mining or emotion AI) is the use of natural language processing, text analysis, computational linguistics, and biometrics to systematically identify, extract, quantify, and study affective states and subjective information.

## Core Task

A basic task in sentiment analysis is classifying the polarity of a given text at the document, sentence, or feature/aspect level—whether the expressed opinion in a document, a sentence or an entity feature/aspect is positive, negative, or neutral.

## Applications

Sentiment analysis is widely applied to voice of the customer materials such as reviews and survey responses, online and social media, and healthcare materials for applications that range from marketing to customer service to clinical medicine. Additionally, investors are known to measure market sentiment through the use of news analytics, which include sentiment analysis on textual stories about companies and sectors.

## Types

There are various other types of sentiment analysis, such as aspect-based sentiment analysis, grading sentiment analysis (positive, negative, neutral), multilingual sentiment analysis and detection of emotions.

## Multimodal Approach

Multimodal sentiment analysis is a technology for traditional text-based sentiment analysis, which includes modalities such as audio and visual data.

Web search results for query: "Microblogging"

Links: [{"title":"Microblogging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging"},{"title":"Microblogging in China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging_in_China"},{"title":"Comparison of microblogging and similar services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_microblogging_and_similar_services"},{"title":"Microblogging novel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging_novel"},{"title":"Micro.blog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro.blog"},{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"}]

Here are the search results for "Microblogging":

## Definition and Overview

Microblogging is a form of blogging using short posts without titles known as microposts or status updates.(no content)Microblogs "allow users to exchange small elements of content such as short sentences, individual images, or video links", which contributes to their popularity.

## Notable Services

Among the most notable services are Twitter, Tumblr, Mastodon, Micro.blog, FriendFeed, Plurk, Jaiku and identi.ca. Additionally, other social networking websites Facebook, MySpace, LinkedIn, Diaspora, JudgIt and XING, also have their own microblogging feature, better known as "status updates".

## Character Limits

Posts typically contain short text, usually 280 characters or less.

## Microblogging in China

Weibo is a general term for microblogging, but normally understood as Chinese-based mini-blogging services, including social chat sites and platform sharing.(no content)Weibo services use a format similar to the American-based Twitter-service, but are used almost exclusively by Chinese language speakers.

Links: [{"title":"Microblogging - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging"},{"title":"Microblogging in China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging_in_China"},{"title":"Comparison of microblogging and similar services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_microblogging_and_similar_services"},{"title":"Microblogging novel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microblogging_novel"},{"title":"Micro.blog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro.blog"},{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"}]

Here are the search results for "Microblogging":

## Definition and Overview

Microblogging is a form of blogging using short posts without titles known as microposts or status updates.(no content)Microblogs "allow users to exchange small elements of content such as short sentences, individual images, or video links", which contributes to their popularity.

## Notable Services

Among the most notable services are Twitter, Tumblr, Mastodon, Micro.blog, FriendFeed, Plurk, Jaiku and identi.ca. Additionally, other social networking websites Facebook, MySpace, LinkedIn, Diaspora, JudgIt and XING, also have their own microblogging feature, better known as "status updates".

## Character Limits

Posts typically contain short text, usually 280 characters or less.

## Microblogging in China

Weibo is a general term for microblogging, but normally understood as Chinese-based mini-blogging services, including social chat sites and platform sharing.(no content)Weibo services use a format similar to the American-based Twitter-service, but are used almost exclusively by Chinese language speakers.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Psychometrics psychological measurement"

Links: [{"title":"Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometrics"},{"title":"Computational psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_psychometrics"},{"title":"Psychometric software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometric_software"},{"title":"Measuring the Mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measuring_the_Mind"},{"title":"Item analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Item_analysis"},{"title":"Psychological statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_statistics"},{"title":"Category:Psychometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Psychometrics"},{"title":"List of schools for quantitative psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_schools_for_quantitative_psychology"},{"title":"Psychometry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychometry"},{"title":"Personality test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_test"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about psychometrics and psychological measurement:

## Definition and Scope

Psychometrics is a field of study within psychology concerned with the theory and technique of measurement, covering specialized fields within psychology and education devoted to testing, measurement, assessment, and related activities.(no content)Psychometrics is concerned with the objective measurement of latent constructs that cannot be directly observed.(no content)Examples of latent constructs include intelligence, personality factors (e.g., introversion), mental disorders, and educational achievement.

## How Psychometrics Works

The levels of individuals on nonobservable latent variables are inferred through mathematical modeling based on what is observed from individuals' responses to items on tests and scales.

## Professionals in the Field

Most psychometricians are psychologists with advanced graduate training in psychometrics and measurement theory.(no content)In addition to traditional academic institutions, psychometricians also work for organizations, such as Pearson and the Educational Testing Service as well as independent consultants.

## Key Approaches and Methods

Some psychometric researchers focus on the construction and validation of assessment instruments, including surveys, scales, and open- or close-ended questionnaires, while others focus on research relating to measurement theory (e.g., item response theory, intraclass correlation) or specialize as learning and development professionals.

The field combines statistical and mathematical modeling to ensure that psychological and educational tests accurately measure what they're intended to measure.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Mood psychology emotion"

Links: [{"title":"Mood (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_(psychology)"},{"title":"Emotion classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion_classification"},{"title":"Emotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion"},{"title":"Affect (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_(psychology)"},{"title":"Affect measures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_measures"},{"title":"Wikipedia:WikiProject Psychology/Emotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:WikiProject_Psychology/Emotion"},{"title":"Mood-dependent memory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood-dependent_memory"},{"title":"Emotional lability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotional_lability"},{"title":"Affective neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affective_neuroscience"},{"title":"Mood management theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mood_management_theory"}]

I've performed the web search for "Mood psychology emotion" and found comprehensive information on this topic. Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Key Distinctions

In psychology, a mood is an affective state that is less specific, less intense, and less likely to be provoked by a particular stimulus or event compared to emotions or feelings.(no content)An emotion tends to have a clear focus with a self-evident cause, while mood tends to be more unfocused and diffuse.

## Duration and Intensity

Moods are basic psychological states that can occur as a reaction to an event or surface for no apparent external cause, and since there is no intentional object causing the mood, it has no specific start and stop date and can last for hours, days, weeks, or longer.

## Effects on Cognition and Behavior

Negative moods can manipulate how individuals interpret and translate the world around them and can also direct their behavior, and can affect an individual's judgment and perception of objects and events. Conversely, positive mood has been found to enhance creative problem solving and flexible thinking, and some studies have shown that positive moods let people think creatively, freely, and be more imaginative.

## Neurobiological Basis

Based on discoveries made through neural mapping of the limbic system, emotion is a pleasant or unpleasant mental state organized in the limbic system of the mammalian brain, in which neurochemicals like dopamine, noradrenaline, and serotonin step-up or step-down the brain's activity level.

This research demonstrates the interconnected but distinct nature of mood and emotion in psychological science.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
